com.brunomnsilva.smartgraph.graphview

Class SmartGraphPanel<V,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.scene.Node
      • javafx.scene.Parent
        • javafx.scene.layout.Region
          • javafx.scene.layout.Pane
            • com.brunomnsilva.smartgraph.graphview.SmartGraphPanel<V,E>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - Type of element stored at a vertex
    E - Type of element stored at an edge
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget

    public class SmartGraphPanel<V,E>
extends javafx.scene.layout.Pane
    JavaFX Pane that is capable of plotting a Graph or Digraph.
    Be sure to call init() after the Stage is displayed.
    Whenever changes to the underlying graph are made, you should call update() to force the rendering of any new elements and, also, the removal of others, if applicable.
    Vertices can be dragged by the user, if configured to do so. Consequently, any connected edges will also adjust automatically to the new vertex positioning.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Runs the initial current vertex placement strategy.

        This method should only be called once during the lifetime of the object and only after the underlying Scene is displayed. Further required updates should be performed through the update() method.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - The exception is thrown if: (1) the Scene is not yet displayed; (2) It has zero width and/or height, and; (3) If this method was already called.

      • automaticLayoutProperty

        public javafx.beans.property.BooleanProperty automaticLayoutProperty()
        Returns the property used to toggle the automatic layout of vertices.
        Returns:
        automatic layout property

      • setAutomaticLayout

        public void setAutomaticLayout(boolean value)
        Toggle the automatic layout of vertices.
        Parameters:
        value - true if enabling; false, otherwise

      • update

        public void update()
        Forces a refresh of the visualization based on current state of the underlying graph, immediately returning to the caller. This method invokes the refresh in the graphical thread through Platform.runLater(), so its not guaranteed that the visualization is in sync immediately after this method finishes. That is, this method immediately returns to the caller without waiting for the update to the visualization.

        New vertices will be added close to adjacent ones or randomly for isolated vertices.

      • updateAndWait

        public void updateAndWait()
        Forces a refresh of the visualization based on current state of the underlying graph and waits for completion of the update. Use this variant only when necessary, e.g., need to style an element immediately after adding it to the underlying graph. Otherwise, use update() instead for performance sake.

        New vertices will be added close to adjacent ones or randomly for isolated vertices.
